Friday, 04. February 2022

KABN Network

Red Beans Nutrition Facts And Benefits

looking for a healthy and nutritious addition to your diet, consider adding some red beans to your meal plan! The common bean is an important food crop and major source of protein throughout the world. The nutrition facts for red beans Red beans are a healthy, protein-rich food that can be enjoyed in many different ways. Here are some nutrition facts about red beans: ‚Ä¢One c

looking for a healthy and nutritious addition to your diet, consider adding some red beans to your meal plan!

The common bean is an important food crop and major source of protein throughout the world.

The nutrition facts for red beans

Red beans are a healthy, protein-rich food that can be enjoyed in many different ways. Here are some nutrition facts about red beans:

‚Ä¢One cup of cooked red beans contains approximately 15 grams of protein. This is important for maintaining muscle mass and preventing weight gain.

‚Ä¢Red beans are also high in fiber, which can help with digestion and weight loss. One cup of cooked red beans contains around 15 grams of fiber.

‚Ä¢Red beans are a good source of antioxidants, which can help protect the body from disease.

They are also low in calories, making them a good choice for people who are trying to lose weight. A one-cup serving of cooked red beans has only around 240 calories.

Overview of plant compounds of red beans

Red beans are a type of legume that is high in plant compounds known as antioxidants. These antioxidants can help protect the body against disease and inflammation. Some of the beneficial plant compounds found in red beans include:

-Anthocyanins: These are a type of antioxidant that give red beans their color. They have been shown to protect the body against heart disease and cancer.

-Isoflavones: These plant compounds have been shown to reduce the risk of heart disease and cancer, as well as improve bone health.

-Fiber: Red beans are a good source of fiber, which can help reduce the risk of heart disease, obesity, and diabetes. Fiber may also help promote gut health by increasing the number of good bacteria in the gut.

Kidney beans Vitamins and minerals

Kidney beans are rich in vitamins and minerals. Some of the key nutrients found in kidney beans include potassium, magnesium, iron, zinc, copper, manganese, and vitamin C. These nutrients play important roles in various aspects of health, including bone health, energy production, immune function, and skin health.

Red beans for Weight loss

Red beans are a great food for weight loss. They‚Äôre low in calories and high in fiber, which makes them satisfying and filling. Plus, they‚Äôre packed with antioxidants and other nutrients that are beneficial for health. Here are some tips for incorporating red beans into your diet:

1. Add them to your favorite salads.

2. Use them as a replacement for ground beef in tacos or burritos.

3. Make a black bean burger with red beans instead of black beans.

4. Mix them with rice and vegetables to make a healthy burrito bowl.

5. Add them to soup or stew recipes.

See more from the source : Red bean benefits

Study shows health benefit of red bean

A recent study found that eating red beans may improve health.

The study, which was published in the journal Nutrients, looked at the effects of consuming red beans on markers of inflammation and oxidative stress.

The researchers found that consuming red beans led to a decrease in levels of inflammatory markers and an increase in levels of antioxidant markers.

This suggests that red beans may help to reduce inflammation and oxidative stress, both of which are associated with a number of chronic diseases.

This is not the first study to find health benefits associated with eating red beans. Previous studies have shown that they can help to improve blood sugar control, lower cholesterol levels, and reduce the risk of heart disease.

So if you‚Äôre looking for a healthy and nutritious addition to your diet, consider adding some red beans to your meal plan!

9 health benefits of beans ( all beans colors)

Beans are a nutritional powerhouse, packing a lot of fiber and protein into a small package. They‚Äôre also low in calories and carbohydrates, making them a great choice if you‚Äôre looking to lose weight or manage your blood sugar levels. Here are ten health benefits of beans:

1. Beans are high in fiber, which can help with weight loss and digestion.

2. Beans are a good source of protein, which can help build muscle mass and keep you feeling full after eating.

3. Beans are low in calories and carbohydrates, making them a great choice for people who are trying to lose weight or manage their blood sugar levels.

4. Beans are high in antioxidants, which can help protect against free radical damage and reduce the risk of cancer and other diseases.

5. Beans contain folate, magnesium, potassium, and other minerals that are essential for health.

6. Beans are gluten-free, making them a good choice for people who have gluten sensitivity or celiac disease.

7. Beans can help regulate blood sugar levels and improve insulin resistance in people with diabetes or prediabetes.

8. Beans may help reduce the risk of heart disease and stroke by lowering cholesterol levels and reducing inflammation throughout the body.

9) Black beans may also help protect against breast cancer due to their phytonutrient content.‚Äù

19:09 • a day ago

OpenID

2022 OpenID Foundation Board Election Results

Thank you to all members who voted in the 2022 elections for representatives to the OpenID Foundation Board of Directors. As per the Foundation‚Äôs bylaws, three individual board members represent the membership and the community at large. Nat Sakimura and John Bradley both have one year remaining on their two-year terms and I welcome their [‚Ä¶] The post 2022 OpenID Foundation Board Election Results

Thank you to all members who voted in the 2022 elections for representatives to the OpenID Foundation Board of Directors.

As per the Foundation‚Äôs bylaws, three individual board members represent the membership and the community at large. Nat Sakimura and John Bradley both have one year remaining on their two-year terms and I welcome their continued thought leadership as the Foundation increases its global reach through the increasing adoption of OpenID standards in 2022 and beyond.

George Fletcher was re-elected to a new two-year term as a Community member representative. I want to thank George for his long-standing service to the Foundation and look forward to his continued contributions in his new role with Capital One.

Each year, Corporate members of the OpenID Foundation elect a member to represent them on the board. All Corporate members in good standing were eligible to nominate and vote for candidates. I want to thank both Chris Michael, CEO and Co-founder at Ozone Financial Technology, and Ashish Jain, Chief Product Officer at Arkose Labs, for nominating themselves for this important board role that requires a substantial investment of time and energy.

I am very pleased to welcome back Ashish Jain to the board as Corporate member representative. Ashish served in this role in 2021 and has been a member of the Strategy & Budget Task Force defining the Foundation‚Äôs strategy and aligning the budget for 2022. I look forward to Ashish‚Äôs ongoing contributions and support in executing the Foundation‚Äôs 2022 strategy.

I also welcome Chris Michael‚Äôs ongoing contributions to Foundation working groups, as well as guidance and support as FAPI adoption increases globally in new markets. Chris‚Äô experience and technical expertise in these markets have been of great value to the Foundation.

Please join me in thanking George and Ashish, as well as the other directors, for their service to the Foundation and the community at large. And thanks to all members for your continued investment of time and membership that drives the Foundation‚Äôs efforts.

 

Gail Hodges
Executive Director
OpenID Foundation

The post 2022 OpenID Foundation Board Election Results first appeared on OpenID.
14:25 • 2 days ago

Ceramic Network

DAOhaus adds functionality for rich member profiles for DAOs

DAOhaus has integrated Ceramic to bring rich profiles to DAO members.

DAOhaus‚Äô mission is to unlock the next tier of community coordination by facilitating the transition from traditional organizations to DAOs.

DAOs are the most powerful way for communities to achieve their shared purpose and live their shared values, and DAOhaus strives to be the best platform for communities to do just that. DAOhaus is home to an ecosystem of hundreds of purpose-driven community DAOs. From giving grants, to building products, bringing together guilds of professionals, and even investing, DAOs using the DAOhaus platform are all focused on one core thing: empowering the humans in their community to achieve their shared purpose and values.

Do you belong to a community with those goals? Summon a DAO today on DAOhaus! Or, if you're looking to find a community that resonates with you, explore the hundreds of DAOs already using DAOhaus.

What is DAOhaus?

The DAOhaus platform is the easiest way for anyone to start a DAO. DAOs are a framework to help communities coordinate and achieve their shared goals.

No clue what a DAO is? Check out this 2 min explainer.

At its core, DAOhaus is a human-friendly way for DAO members to engage in the activities that allow them to collectively manage common resources in service of a shared purpose, without relying on trusted executives. With DAOhaus, you can:

Form (‚Äúsummon‚Äù) a new DAO Issue members "Shares" representing voting power and economic exit rights  (aka ‚Äúragequit‚Äù) Set up a shared Treasury that is controlled collectively by all members Make and vote on proposals with Shares Extending the functionality of DAO tooling

DAOhaus also empowers DAOs beyond these foundational activities. For example, using a feature called Minions, DAOs can interact with any external smart contract, for example to make a deposit into another DeFi protocol, buy an NFT, or disperse tokens to multiple recipients. Minions can also have more narrowly-scoped functionality, such as with our Superfluid Minion that allows a DAO to send and receive token streams (think sending contributors a continuous stream of payment rather than a lump sump after all work has been delivered).

These Minions are one kind of DAOhaus Boost, which are add-ons that DAOs can optionally install to expand their capabilities. Some Boosts are built by the DAOhaus core contributors, though many are built by community developers. All Boosts are discoverable, installable and configurable through the DAOhaus Boost Marketplace. Some examples of Boosts include Rarible Boost (which helps you buy & sell NFTs on Rarible) and Disperse Boost (which allows you to transfer tokens to other addresses).

DAOhaus aims to support purpose-driven community DAOs wherever they may be, and as such the platform is available on Ethereum Mainnet, xDai Polygon, Arbitrum, and Celo, with support for more EVM-compatible networks on the way!

The need for context around DAO member identity

DAOs are human-centric communities. With DAOhaus, DAO members make decisions and take collective action by coordinating explicitly with each other. It is imperative that DAO members are able to identify one another (whether with real names or pseudonymously) and have a shared understanding of who is involved in their community - whether that be leading a working group or submitting, sponsoring or voting on a given proposal. Without easy access to that context, members have difficulty navigating the social landscape of their DAO, which magnifies coordination overhead and stunts the community‚Äôs cultural evolution.

Account-based DAO member identities create friction in coordination

Identity in web3, as is the case in most DAOs today, is typically address based. Users represent themselves as their wallet or account address, but long hex strings are not sufficient. While ENS names are great for Ethereum mainnet, they don‚Äôt currently work across all the networks DAOhaus supports. Users need a human-readable identity solution that works across networks and the many tools DAOs commonly use.

Additionally, today DAOhaus relies on several centralized storage and API endpoints for things like DAO metadata (e.g., names, tags, descriptions, social media links, etc.) and Boost settings. As the team moves towards a more modular and open architecture to allow developers to further extend the platform and more easily build Boosts, they've begun migrating towards more decentralized storage and data solutions.

"We needed a performant, decentralized storage solution to store user data, and Ceramic was the obvious choice," - Keating, DAOhaus core contributor
Embedding identity as a coordination mechanism

To help DAOs better understand who is participating in thier communities, DAOhaus is using Ceramic to create rich and robust member profiles. Using Ceramic‚Äôs Self.ID to collect and display member names, avatars and emojis, members can now add clarity and a touch of personalization to their DAOhaus identity.

DAOhaus users can edit their Self.Id identity in the Profile section of any DAO they are involved in.

Create once, replicate many Interoperability across web3

Since Self.ID is built on Ceramic's permissionless data network, all user data stored in their profiles are:

User-controlled: users own their own data and decide how and when applications can access it Composable & portable: application developers can access data from this shared data layer (if users already have a Self.Id created, the data will be displayed automatically within the DAOhaus app, and displayed in every other web3 app that uses Ceramic for profiles) Decentralized: data is stored in a decentralized manner, so no single application can censor, shut down or delete your data Multi-chain: with Ceramic, users can connect multiple accounts and wallets to a single DID to create a unified identity Unified, human-readable identities create more robust communities & reputation systems

Member profiles are available today on DAOhaus. Looking ahead, the team is exploring using Ceramic to power decentralized data for DAO organizational profiles, as well as metadata, Boost configuration, rich marketplace metadata, and more.

Having an identity controlled by a DAO framework enables a DAO to represent itself within web3 protocols and applications. The DAO identity would be represented as a decentralized identifier (DID) created on Ceramic, which could be linked to a multi-signature account (such as a Gnosis Safe) or Moloch DAO, ensuring multiple participants would need to sign off before any changes are made to any data. In this way, DAOs would be able to write and store data directly to the Ceramic network.

What's next for DAOhaus?

Core contributors of DAOhaus have released a new version of Minion that uses the Gnosis Zodiac protocol to allow a DAO to control a Gnosis Safe, adding new capabilities such as expedited execution of proposals and the ability to pull funds from the DAO Treasury in Minion proposals.

The DAOhaus community has been busy too, adding, among other things, two new Boosts in the Boost Marketplace: the Rarible Boost, which enables DAOs to to buy and sell NFTs, and the Disperse Boost, which enables DAOs to distribute tokens to multiple recipients in a single proposal.

Beyond these product releases, the team has been busy launching other community initiatives and onboarding more DAOs! If you want to see what else the team has accomplished in 2021, check out their Year in Review.

Looking forward, the team is preparing to support the new MolochV3 (Baal) DAO framework, which will add even more flexibility for DAOs. The new framework would give DAOs more support throughout the entire lifecycle, from additional options for summoning a new DAO, to vote delegation, embedded Minion functionality, and the ability to make Shares transferable. The team is also working on expanding support for additional L2 networks and sidechains, such as Optimism and potentially Fantom.

If you‚Äôre a member of an existing community looking to level up its coordination powers, or interested in starting a new community yourself, you can summon a DAO today with DAOhaus!

If you‚Äôre a developer or builder looking to contribute, hop into the DAOhaus Discord & let the community know! The community is actively looking for contributors to help build more Boosts to give DAOs even better tooling to pursue their purpose.

If you just want to learn more about DAOs, follow the team on Twitter (@nowdaoit) and Substack, or head to daohaus.club.

Website | Twitter | Discord | GitHub | Documentation | Blog | IDX Identity

eSSIF-Lab

eSSIF-Lab workshop: Building an SSI ecosystem together

This workshop features six eSSIF-Lab subgrantees, who will provide you with live demos of their solutions.

REGISTER HERE for this event!üëà

Where: This event is taking place online. After the registration, you will receive the link to join the online session, via your email.

When: 25th of February 2022

About the event

Are you looking for identity solutions that improve the interaction between citizens and organisation, reducing administrative overhead and delays, while also satisfying high privacy, security and trust standards? Are you curious about the capabilities of state-of-the-art solutions in this area?

The European NGI eSSIF-Lab programme has been providing grants to stimulate the development of a European Self-Sovereign-Identity (SSI) ecosystem. Subgrantees are developing SSI (open-source) components, products and services: some generic (wallet infrastructure, trust infrastructure, SSI libraries) and other sector-specific (eHealth, eGovernment, education). Example applications are identification of roaming medical staff, digital certificates of conduct and digital diplomas. Subgrantee projects demonstrate interoperability between the different solutions, integration of components into larger solutions, and contribution to (pre)standardisation in ToIP, DIF, W3C and OIDC.

This workshop features six eSSIF-Lab subgrantees, who will provide you with live demos of their solutions as well as insight into how these can be applied to solve real-world problems.

Agenda

16:00 Welcome

16:05 eSSIF-Lab ‚Äì Building an SSI ecosystem together

Oskar van Deventer, TNO, Scientific Coordinator of eSSIF-Lab

16:20 WordPreSSI ‚Äì WordPress plugin that eliminates username-password logins

Fabio Lecca, Associazione Blockchain Italia

16:35 Automated Data Agreements ‚Äì Making data transactions trustworthy, auditable and immutable

Lal Chandran, iGrant.io

16:50 Walt-ID ‚Äì Universal SSI Wallet Infrastructure for Europe

Dominique Beron, Walt.ID

17:05 Break

17:20 Presentation Exchange ‚Äì Query any credential from any SSI wallet

Niels Klomp, Sphereon

17:35 Verifier Universal Interface ‚Äì Standard APIs for credential verification

Irene Hernandez, Gataca

17:50 Discussion

18:00 Closing

This event is free and open to all stakeholders.

We Are Open co-op

Join the Keep Badges Weird Community Call!

The Keep Badges Weird community is steadily growing, and it comes at a perfect time. People who are interested in Open Recognition, people who are using badges for new and weird things, these folks need a place to discuss the world of open badges. A place that is community driven, a place in which we reflect on our world and what community and kindness can do to make it a better place. Poetry

The Keep Badges Weird community is steadily growing, and it comes at a perfect time. People who are interested in Open Recognition, people who are using badges for new and weird things, these folks need a place to discuss the world of open badges. A place that is community driven, a place in which we reflect on our world and what community and kindness can do to make it a better place.

Poetry & design cc-by Laura Hilliger and illustration cc-by-nd Bryan Mathers of We Are Open

Keep Badges Weird is just that: we‚Äôve been having fun making the world a better place by inventing stealth badges, starting discussions, reflecting on the open badges ecosystem, wondering aloud about market forces and otherwise grouping together to see how our networks can push forward communities of practice in the 21st century.

Keep Badges Weird is maturing as a community, and if there‚Äôs one thing that growing communities need, it‚Äôs synchronous interaction.

It is no secret that I absolutely LOVE community calls. The how-to guide I wrote years ago is one of my all time most shared posts. So imagine how absolutely jazzed I am to get a Keep Badges Weird community call going. We know that community calls are excellent ways to build solidarity and connections.

This community is exploring the intersection between communities of practice and badges, and we‚Äôve got big ideas to play around with. Joining the call will provide the KBW community with immediate value! Your voice, your enthusiasm and even your presence will change the dynamic of the room and we heartily invite you all to come and join us.

Mark your calendar for next Thursday, February 10th at 16:00 UTC. Here‚Äôs a handy timezone converter.

Not a member of the KBW community yet? Join, introduce yourself, have a look around and then join us on Thursday, February 10th!

All the Details When? 10th of February; 16:00 UTC (what time is that for me?) Where? Zoom What? Kick off the community & run this agenda

Join the Keep Badges Weird Community Call! was originally published in We Are Open Co-op on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

22:02 • 5 days ago

KABN Network

Count Calories better, Diet Healthier‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäGuide Of All What You Need To Know

Count Calories Better, Diet Healthier‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäGuide Of All What You Need To Know The Dos and Don‚Äôts of Counting Calories Do: When it comes to counting calories, there are a few dos that will help you stay on track and achieve your weight loss goals. Use a diet calories calculator app or website to track your intake. This will ensure accuracy and make it easier to stay on track.
Count Calories Better, Diet Healthier‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäGuide Of All What You Need To Know The Dos and Don‚Äôts of Counting Calories Do:

When it comes to counting calories, there are a few dos that will help you stay on track and achieve your weight loss goals.

Use a diet calories calculator app or website to track your intake. This will ensure accuracy and make it easier to stay on track. Read the nutrition labels of all foods you eat. This will help you know how many calories are in each serving. Create a calorie budget for yourself, and try to stick to it. This will help you lose weight gradually and safely. Do make sure to include all foods and beverages in your calorie count. This includes those pesky little extras like condiments and sugar-free beverages. Do be honest with yourself about how many calories you need to lose weight. If you want to lose 1‚Äì2 pounds per week, then aim to consume 500‚Äì1000 fewer calories than you burn each day. Do adjust your calorie intake as needed. If you hit a plateau or if you start gaining weight, then adjust your calorie intake accordingly. A good rule of thumb is to reduce your intake by 100‚Äì200 calories per day until you start seeing results again. Do focus on healthy foods that are low in calories but high in nutrients. This will help ensure that you are getting the most out of your diet while still losing weight. Some great options include vegetables, fruits, lean protein, and whole grains.‚Äù

Check also: Red bean benefits

Don‚Äôt:

If you‚Äôre trying to lose weight, counting calories is a great way to do it. But there are a few things you should avoid if you want to see results. Here are four don‚Äôts of counting calories:

Count calories without also considering other factors such as protein, carbohydrates, and fat. All of these nutrients play important roles in your health and should be taken into account when counting calories. Skip meals or go too long between meals. This can cause you to become ravenous and overeat later on. Obsess over every little calorie that you consume. Life is meant to be enjoyed, and obsessing over every calorie will only lead to stress and unhealthy eating habits. Don‚Äôt forget about fiber. Fiber is another important nutrient, and it‚Äôs especially important when dieting. Make sure you‚Äôre getting enough fiber each day to help keep you full and support your weight loss goals Don‚Äôt forget about carbs. Carbs are also an important part of a healthy diet, and they‚Äôre especially important when dieting. Make sure you‚Äôre getting enough carbs each day to help burn fat and fuel your workouts. Don‚Äôt forget about protein. Protein is an important part of a healthy diet, and it‚Äôs especially important when dieting. Make sure you‚Äôre getting enough protein each day to help burn fat and build muscle. Don‚Äôt overdo it. It‚Äôs important not to eat too few calories, as this can actually slow down your metabolism and make it more difficult to lose weight. Try to find the right balance for you, and don‚Äôt cut more than 500‚Äì750 calories per day. The Pros and Cons of Calorie Counting

Calorie counting is a popular way to keep track of the number of calories you eat each day.

This can be an effective way to lose weight or maintain a healthy weight. However, there are some pros and cons to calorie counting. The Pros of Calorie Counting

You are in control of your food choices. When you are calorie counting, you are able to choose the foods that fit within your daily calorie budget. This can help you make healthier food choices and avoid unhealthy foods.

2. It is an easy way to track progress. By keeping track of the number of calories you consume each day, you can see how your diet changes over time. This can be helpful in monitoring your progress and seeing if your current diet is working for you.

3. It helps you become more aware of portion sizes. Often when we don‚Äôt count calories, we tend to underestimate how much we are actually eating. Calorie counting can help teach you about proper portion sizes and how much food constitutes a serving size.

4. It may increase your metabolism . Some research has shown that people who calorie count may have a higher metabolic rate than those who do not count calories . This could lead to more successful weight loss in the long run.

The Cons of Calorie Counting

1 . It can be time consuming . Keeping track of every calorie that goes into your mouth can be a tedious process .

2 . You may become obsessed with numbers . Focusing too much on numbers can lead to eating disorders and unhealthy relationships with food .

3 . You might develop restrictive eating habits . Restricting yourself from certain foods can cause negative thoughts about food and body image issues

How to make Calorie counting effective Make sure you‚Äôre accurately counting your calories. A lot of people make mistakes when counting, either by underestimating or overestimating the number of calories in their food. Use a calorie tracking app or website to get an accurate estimate of the calories in your meals.

2. Don‚Äôt obsess over every little thing. If you eat a cookie or have a slice of pizza, don‚Äôt worry‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääjust adjust your calorie intake for the rest of the day to make up for it. Trying to be perfect can be counterproductive and lead to feelings of guilt and frustration.

3. Find a method that works for you. Some people prefer to track their calories manually, while others find it more helpful to use an app or online calculator. Figure out what works best for you and stick with it.

4. Be patient. Losing weight takes time, so don‚Äôt expect results overnight. Stick with it for several weeks before deciding if calorie counting is right for you.

5. Make a list of foods that you enjoy and that are healthy. This will help you stay on track with your diet and make it more enjoyable.

6. Try to stick to healthy, nutrient-rich foods as much as possible. This will help you meet your nutritional needs while keeping your calorie intake in check.

7. Avoid processed foods whenever possible. These tend to be high in unhealthy fats, sugars and sodium, which can sabotage your weight loss efforts.

8. Drink plenty of water and avoid sugary drinks. Water is essential for good health and helps keep you feeling full throughout the day. Sugary drinks are packed with empty calories and can quickly derail your diet plans.

conclusion

We do Counting Calories for three purposes:

If you‚Äôre trying to lose weight:

Counting calories is a great way to help achieve your goals. There are many online tools and apps that can help with this.

Second, make sure you‚Äôre burning more calories than you‚Äôre eating. This can be done through exercise and physical activity.

Finally, give yourself time. It may take a while for your body to adjust to your new calorie intake, so be patient and keep up with your healthy habits.

Check also: Best parsley tea bags

If you are looking to gain weight:

You need to consume more calories than you burn. The average person needs around 2,000‚Äì2,500 calories per day to maintain their weight, so if you want to gain weight, you‚Äôll need to eat more than that.

It‚Äôs best to spread your extra calories throughout the day, with three main meals and a couple of snacks in between. You can use a calorie calculator to help you determine how many calories you should be eating each day.

If you are looking to maintain weight:

By simply eat as much as you burn.

21:41 • 5 days ago

Trust over IP

The ToIP Foundation Releases its First Official Governance Specifications

These are tools that CIOs, CISOs, Chief Privacy Officers, trust architects, and other policymakers can begin using immediately to construct governance frameworks. The post The ToIP Foundation Releases its First Official Governance Specifications appeared first on Trust Over IP.

The Trust Over IP (ToIP) Foundation today announced the release of its first two official specifications for ToIP-compliant governance frameworks (aka trust frameworks):

The ToIP Governance Architecture Specification V1.0 (PDF). The ToIP Governance Metamodel Specification V1.0 (PDF).

Produced by the ToIP Governance Stack Working Group (GSWG), these two specifications together with the ToIP Governance Metamodel Specification Companion Guide V1.0 are tools that CIOs, CISOs, Chief Privacy Officers, trust architects, and other policymakers can begin using immediately to construct a governance framework for any of the four ToIP layers of decentralized digital trust infrastructure.

‚ÄúIn our first 18 months the GSWG has produced 11 deliverables,‚Äù said GSWG co-chair Scott Perry, Principal of the Crypto and Digital Trust Services practice at Schellman, a leading global provider of attestation, compliance, and certification services. ‚ÄúThese are the first two official ToIP specifications that define what a governance framework must include to comply with the ToIP model.‚Äù

These specifications and the Companion Guide have already been used to craft the first governance frameworks for ToIP-based digital trust ecosystems. ‚ÄúWhen the Yoma  (Youth Agency Marketplace) project needed decentralized governance, starting with the ToIP governance model saved us months of time,‚Äù said Lohan Spies, CTO of Yoma. ‚ÄúIt also helped us produce a governance framework in which all the major stakeholders‚ÄîYoma, Generation Unlimited, GIZ, youth, service providers, donors, developers‚Äîhad confidence.‚Äù

These three deliverables are also the first from ToIP to incorporate terms from the ToIP Foundation‚Äôs cross-industry glossary development project. ‚ÄúThe subjects of digital identity and trust are extremely challenging to discuss with great clarity,‚Äù said Drummond Reed, who co-chairs both the GSWG and the ToIP Concepts and Terminology Working Group (CTWG). ‚ÄúThese deliverables use the CTWG terms wiki and glossary development tools to link together terms curated by experts in each relevant domain.‚Äù

About the Governance Half of the ToIP Stack

The mission of the ToIP Foundation is to define a complete architecture for Internet-scale digital trust that combines cryptographic assurance at the machine layer with human accountability at the business, legal, and social layers. This four-layer architecture is referred to as the ToIP stack, summarized in this diagram (and in this interactive model):

This diagram highlights that the ToIP stack is fundamentally composed of two halves:

The technology stack defines the technical standards and protocols needed to establish interoperable technical trust (aka cryptographic trust) at each of the four layers. The governance stack defines the requirements for governance frameworks (aka trust frameworks) to specify the policies and rules the members of a community need to follow to achieve institutional trust (aka human trust) at each of the four layers.

The central premise of the ToIP model is that neither half alone is sufficient to achieve interoperable decentralized digital trust infrastructure. You must have both halves working together.

About the ToIP Governance Architecture Specification V1.0

A specific governance framework is designed for a specific layer of the ToIP stack (public utility, agent/wallet, credential, or ecosystem). However, certain interoperability requirements apply to all ToIP-compliant governance frameworks regardless of layer. The purpose of this relatively short (10 page) specification is to specify those overall requirements. It consists of five sections:

Identification‚Äîthe requirements for ToIP governance framework documents‚Äîand the parties they govern‚Äîto be identified by persistent, verifiable, globally unique decentralized identifiers (DIDs). Verification‚Äîthe requirements for ToIP governance framework documents to be digitally signed by their governing authorities‚Äîand for all governed parties to have a means of cryptographically verifying the GF role in which they are serving using either a verifiable credential, a trust registry, or both. Transparency‚Äîthe requirements for any publicly-available ToIP governance framework document to be published on the Web and discoverable via its DID. It also covers localization and accessibility. Technical Interoperability‚Äîthe requirements for a ToIP governance framework to specify technical interop using the ToIP Technology Stack. ToIP Governance Metamodel‚Äîthe requirement to comply with the ToIP Governance Metamodel Specification (below). About the ToIP Governance Metamodel Specification V1.0 and Companion Guide

The standard structure of a ToIP-compliant governance framework‚Äîthe documents it should include, and the content required or recommended in each document‚Äîwere extensive enough that these were broken into a separate 13-page specification that is divided into two parts:

Primary Document. This is the ‚Äúmaster document‚Äù or ‚Äúhome page‚Äù of a ToIP governance framework. The specification covers the following 13 sections of this document: Introduction Terminology and Notation Localization Governing Authority Administering Authority Purpose Scope Objectives Principles General Requirements Revisions Extensions Schedule of Controlled Documents Controlled Documents. These are subdocuments that form component ‚Äúmodules‚Äù of a ToIP-compliant governance framework. This modular architecture is recommended to simplify revisions and delegate policymaking to the most appropriate parties. Glossary Risk Assessment Trust Assurance and Certification Governance Requirements Business Requirements Technical Requirements Information Trust Requirements (security, privacy, confidentiality, etc.) Inclusion, Equitability, and Accessibility Requirements Legal Agreements

The GSWG also produced the ToIP Governance Metamodel Specification Companion Guide V1.0 to serve as 28-page ‚Äúusers manual‚Äù intended to give governance framework authors the background, context, and guidelines they need in the drafting process. It also suggests the policy areas for which the authors may want to consult subject matter experts (SMEs) within their own community and/or external professionals.

Future Specifications Coming from the GSWG

With this milestone accomplished, the next goal of the GSWG is to produce layer-specific templates for ToIP-compliant governance frameworks. These templates will specify the roles and processes, and governance best practices recommended for each of the four layers of the ToIP stack. Look for future announcements coming from the ToIP Foundation about these templates.If you have a particular interest in decentralized digital trust governance, we invite you to join the work of the ToIP Governance Stack Working Group. Please contact us via the ToIP website.

The post The ToIP Foundation Releases its First Official Governance Specifications appeared first on Trust Over IP.

17:00 • 5 days ago

Oasis Open

XACML v3.0 Dynamic Attribute Authority v1.0 approved as a Committee Specification

A primary use case for the Dynamic Attribute Authority is role enablement. The post XACML v3.0 Dynamic Attribute Authority v1.0 approved as a Committee Specification appeared first on OASIS Open.

New XACML system component is ready for testing and implementation

OASIS is pleased to announce the approval and publication of a new Committee Specification by the members of the eXtensible Access Control Markup Language (XACML) TC [1]:

XACML v3.0 Dynamic Attribute Authority Version 1.0
Committee Specification 01
25 January 2022

Overview

This specification defines a new XACML system component, the Dynamic Attribute Authority, which augments the request context of an XACML authorization request with additional attributes and attribute values that are generated on demand according to a set of rules. The rules are expressed as XACML policies, use obligations to specify the additional attributes and values, and are processed in the normal manner of a Policy Decision Point. This means that a Dynamic Attribute Authority can be readily constructed from existing XACML system components.

A primary use case for the Dynamic Attribute Authority is role enablement, where the dynamic attribute in question is the subject role.

This Committee Specification is an OASIS deliverable, completed and approved by the TC and fully ready for testing and implementation.

The documents and related files are available here:

Editable source (Authoritative):
https://docs.oasis-open.org/xacml/xacml-3.0-dyn-attr/v1.0/cs01/xacml-3.0-dyn-attr-v1.0-cs01.docx

HTML:
https://docs.oasis-open.org/xacml/xacml-3.0-dyn-attr/v1.0/cs01/xacml-3.0-dyn-attr-v1.0-cs01.html

PDF:
https://docs.oasis-open.org/xacml/xacml-3.0-dyn-attr/v1.0/cs01/xacml-3.0-dyn-attr-v1.0-cs01.pdf

Distribution ZIP file

For your convenience, OASIS provides a complete package of the prose specification and related files in a ZIP distribution file. You can download the ZIP file here:

https://docs.oasis-open.org/xacml/xacml-3.0-dyn-attr/v1.0/cs01/xacml-3.0-dyn-attr-v1.0-cs01.zip

Members of the eXtensible Access Control Markup Language (XACML) TC [1] approved this specification by Special Majority Vote. The specification had been released for public review as required by the TC Process [2]. The vote to approve as a Committee Specification passed [3], and the document is now available online in the OASIS Library as referenced above.

Our congratulations to the TC on achieving this milestone and our thanks to the reviewers who provided feedback on the specification drafts to help improve the quality of the work.

Additional references

[1] eXtensible Access Control Markup Language (XACML) TC
https://www.oasis-open.org/committees/xacml/

[2] Details of public review:
‚Äì https://docs.oasis-open.org/xacml/xacml-3.0-dyn-attr/v1.0/csd01/xacml-3.0-dyn-attr-v1.0-csd01-public-review-metadata.html

[3] Approval ballot:
https://www.oasis-open.org/committees/ballot.php?id=3683

The post XACML v3.0 Dynamic Attribute Authority v1.0 approved as a Committee Specification appeared first on OASIS Open.

Ceramic Network

Build more powerful data applications at EthDenver 2022

We‚Äôre excited to return as the official sponsors for EthDenver, awarding up to $15,000 in prizes to the best hacks

Finally, back together again. The 3Box Labs team will be arriving at the Sports Castle in full force this year, elated to see the community reconvening after the 2021 hiatus. We‚Äôre thrilled to announce that we‚Äôll be joining this developer-first event as a Sponsor again this year. We exist to empower web3 builders and are excited to support more developers than ever during both the live and virtual hackathons. If you‚Äôre heading to Denver, make sure to stop by our booth to chat sovereign data, composable apps, and all things Web3 -- and to grab a limited edition Ceramic beanie!

If you‚Äôre interested in getting involved, it‚Äôs not too late to join! Submit your application here.

What‚Äôs Ceramic?

For those not yet familiar, Ceramic‚Äôs decentralized data protocol and identity system gives developers a complete solution for managing user and application data on the open web. With Ceramic, Developers can build decentralized applications that easily store, update and retrieve data from a shared network. Think IPFS, but mutable.

Additionally, this data is written and managed by users themselves, as compared to application developers. On Ceramic, data is controlled by decentralized identifiers (DIDs) that allow users to create a unified digital self by linking data and accounts from various wallets, chains and platforms. Developers can leverage Ceramic‚Äôs shared infrastructure to easily reuse data across applications. With Ceramic, users can create a single profile that multiple apps can read and present uniquely on their respective front-ends, instead of tirelessly replicating their data for the application‚Äôs benefit.

If you want to dig deeper, check out this short workshop for an overview of Ceramic.

Updates from the 3Box Labs team

We've been blown away by the amount of progress made across the Ceramic ecosystem over the last 12 months. Ceramic mainnet was launched in a private preview for Early Launch Partners, dozens of projects have onboarded and are running their own nodes on the network, and 3Box Labs has launched our new Glaze tooling which offers improvements on the former IDX protocol, now referred to as DID Datastore. We‚Äôve also launched v1 of Datamodels, which is a key step towards the long-term vision of Ceramic. As we start enabling developers to publish, share and eventually curate Datamodels on Ceramic, we move closer towards the vision of an interoperable, highly composable data ecosystem that enables a sovereign web.

We‚Äôll be announcing a major milestone for the 3Box Labs team at EthDenver, that will allow us to continue executing on our roadmap, including improving network performance and reliability, building out new capability systems for more advanced permissioning, and launching new streamtypes and features for social use cases. We‚Äôre thrilled to be working alongside so many amazing web3 developers interested in building a more open and inclusive web, together.

How we‚Äôre showing up at EthDenver

Ceramic‚Äôs core protocol and surrounding tooling are more advanced than ever before. The sovereign web is just within reach, and it will require a motivated and coordinated community to build the applications, datamodels and tooling needed to make it a reality. The core primitives of Ceramic itself were developed right here at EthDenver, so we believe in the caliber of ideas and projects that can originate out of the Sports Castle. We can‚Äôt wait to experiment together this year, with our three co-founders offering live support to hackers and awarding over $15,000 to the best hacks at the end of the weekend. Full bounty details will be released soon, so stay tuned!

Come find us

Follow us on Twitter for the latest team updates, or for real-time updates during the event follow:

Co-Founder & CEO Michael Sena (@somemikesena) Co-Foundeer & COO Danny Zuckerman (@dazuck) Co-Founder & CTO Joel Thorstensson (‚Äã‚Äã@joelthorst) Head of Business Development Lauren Feld (@web3lauren) Partner Engineer Rohan Dasika (@rohandasika)

Whether you‚Äôre a returning EthDenver hacker, transitioning web2 engineer, NFT artist, or just simply crypto curious - we‚Äôd love to chat with you IRL. We‚Äôll be announcing our BUIDL Week workshops, conference panels and side events soon!

Resources

Looking to get a jump on the competition? Check out our docs and tutorials to learn more about how to build with Ceramic:

And of course, make sure to join our Ceramic Discord Community to chat with our core team and to get support as you‚Äôre building! Best of luck to all the hackers!

KABN Network

What Is really matters to make diet calories calculators work

What Is Really Matters to Make Diet Calories Calculators Work To use a calories calculator, you need to know how many calories you need per day and how many calories are in the food you‚Äôre eating. While it‚Äôs important to know how many calories are in the food you‚Äôre eating, it‚Äôs even more important to make healthy choices when it comes to what you‚Äôre eating. A calories calculator can be a h
What Is Really Matters to Make Diet Calories Calculators Work

To use a calories calculator, you need to know how many calories you need per day and how many calories are in the food you‚Äôre eating.

While it‚Äôs important to know how many calories are in the food you‚Äôre eating, it‚Äôs even more important to make healthy choices when it comes to what you‚Äôre eating. A calories calculator can be a helpful tool, but it‚Äôs not everything. Here we will cover what really matters.

How many calories do I need each day?

This is a difficult question to answer without knowing more about your lifestyle and activity level.

The recommended calorie intake for the average, sedentary person is about 1200‚Äì2000 per day. If you are moderately active, you may need closer to 2000‚Äì2500 per day.

And if you are very active, you may need upwards of 2500‚Äì3000 or more. To calculate your specific calorie needs, use an online calculator or speak with a registered dietitian. Also we are going to cover the topic in depth.

In general, your daily caloric intake should include: 45‚Äì65% carbohydrates, 20‚Äì35% protein, and 10‚Äì30% fat.

What are macros and why do they matter?

Macronutrients are the three main nutrients that our body needs in order to function: carbohydrates, protein, and fat.

Each of these nutrients play different roles in our health and metabolism, so it‚Äôs important to make sure we are getting enough of all of them. Tracking your macros can be a helpful way to make sure you‚Äôre hitting your nutrient goals for the day.

There are many online calculators and apps that can help you track your macros. A good starting point is calculating what percentage of each nutrient you should aim for each day (see question #1). From there, you can adjust as needed depending on your specific goals and preferences.

(USDA) guidelines:

Calorie and macronutrient guidelines can be helpful in determining how many of each nutrient to eat each day. However, it is important to remember that everyone‚Äôs body is different and what works for one person may not work for another. It is also important to listen to your own body and make adjustments as needed. A good place to start when calculating calorie and macronutrient intake is to use the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) guidelines. The USDA recommends that adult women consume 2,000 calories per day, adult men consume 2,500 calories per day, and children between the ages of 4 and 8 years consume 1,400‚Äì1,600 calories per day. Regarding macronutrients, the USDA recommends that 45‚Äì65% of daily caloric intake come from carbohydrates, 20‚Äì35% from protein, and 10‚Äì35% from fat.

Formulas diet calories calculator uses (exposing the back end algos)

The Harris Benedict formula:

The Harris Benedict Formula is a mathematical equation that calculates someone‚Äôs basal metabolic rate (BMR).

This is the number of calories a person needs to consume each day to maintain their current weight. It takes into account a person‚Äôs sex, height, weight, and age.

Equations:

There are a number of ways to calculate Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR), but the Harris Benedict Formula is one of the most common.

To use the Harris Benedict Formula, you‚Äôll need to know your weight in pounds and your height in inches.

multiply your weight by 703 divide that number by your height in inches add 655 4. if you‚Äôre a woman, subtract 456 5. if you‚Äôre a man, add 68 Your BMR is then the result of this calculation.

Mifflin-St Jeor formula:

The Mifflin-St Jeor equation is a formula used to calculate the basal metabolic rate (BMR), which is the number of calories your body needs to maintain its current weight. The equation takes into account your sex, age, and weight.

Equations:

To calculate BMR, you use the Mifflin-St Jeor equation, which takes into account your sex, age, weight and height.

To use the equation, you first need to determine your basal metabolic rate factor (BMRF), which is a number that reflects how many calories your body burns at rest.

You can find BMRF by dividing your weight in kilograms by your height in meters squared.

Once you have your BMRF, you can use the following equation to calculate BMR:

BMR = 10 x BMRF + 665

For example, if you weigh 60 kg and are 1.7 meters tall (68 inches), your BMR would be: 10 x 0.924 + 665 = 1,608

Owen formula:

The Owen equation is a mathematical formula used to calculate the cardiac output, or the amount of blood pumped by the heart each minute.

The equation is named for Dr. John H. Owen, who developed it in the early 1900s. The equation takes into account a number of factors, including the heart rate, the stroke volume (the amount of blood ejected from the heart with each beat), and the resistance to blood flow throughout the body.

Equations:

Owen equation to calculate your BRM:

BRM = 370 + (9.8 x weight in kg) + (6.8 x height in cm)‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää(4.7 x age in years)

For example, a 30-year-old woman who weighs 70 kg and is 170 cm tall would have a basal metabolic rate of 1,537 calories per day.

Katch-McArdle formula:

You can use the Katch-McArdle formulas to calculate your BMR if you know your lean body mass.

Equations:

The Katch-McArdle formulas are: BMR = 370 + (21.6 x lean body mass) or BMR = (9.8 x weight in kilograms) + (4.7 x height in centimeters)‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää(4.7 x age in years)

Now what?!

After you find your BMR use one of these multipliers to find the amount of calories you need to stay at the same weight

The American Council on Exercise (ACE) has developed the following activity factor multipliers:

sedentary lifestyle = 1.2

light activity = 1.375

moderate activity = 1.55

heavy activity = 1.725

A sedentary lifestyle means you lead a relatively inactive lifestyle, with light physical activity only a few times a week.

If you have a light activity level, that means you engage in some exercise or physical activity on most days of the week but it‚Äôs not very intense.

Moderate activity means you are regularly active and heavy activity means you are very active‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääyou probably have a physically demanding job or workout intensely several times a week.

The Key To Make It Work:

Now a note, all Calorie Counts Are Wrong as scientific american explained Why. But its not wrong to relay on them in the condition of you now they are just guessing efforts by great scientists. The wise decision is to use numbers generated by diet calories calculators as a starting point. If you do so you can make them work.

23:14 • 5 days ago

How To Achieve Your Weight Goals:Controlling Calories In And Calories Out

There are a few problems with online calorie calculators. First, they can be inaccurate. Second, they can be difficult to use. And third, they can be expensive. If you don‚Äôt get enough calories, your body will start breaking down muscle tissue to use as energy. This can lead to a loss of muscle mass, which can make it harder to stay active and healthy. Additionally, if you don‚Äôt eat enough

There are a few problems with online calorie calculators. First, they can be inaccurate. Second, they can be difficult to use. And third, they can be expensive.

If you don‚Äôt get enough calories, your body will start breaking down muscle tissue to use as energy.

This can lead to a loss of muscle mass, which can make it harder to stay active and healthy. Additionally, if you don‚Äôt eat enough calories, you may not have enough energy to do the things you enjoy or to work hard at your job.

Where did the humble calorie come from:

The calorie is a unit of energy that was first defined by the French scientist Nicolas Leonard Sadi Carnot in 1824. A calorie is the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of 1 gram of water by 1 degree Celsius.

The calorie calculator can help you determine how many calories you should eat each day to reach your weight loss goals. It takes into account your basal metabolic rate (the number of calories your body burns at rest), as well as the number of calories you burn through physical activity. If you use application doing so then be sure that you are getting right information about your calorie needs.

How do you figure out how much calorie you need per day

To figure out how many calories you need per day, you‚Äôll need to first calculate your basal metabolic rate (BMR). This is the number of calories your body needs to maintain its current weight at rest.

You can use an online BMR calculator to estimate this number. Once you have your BMR, you‚Äôll need to multiply it by an activity factor.

This number accounts for the amount of activity you do on a daily basis.

If you‚Äôre sedentary, use a multiplier of 1.2; if you‚Äôre moderately active, use 1.3‚Äì1.4; if you‚Äôre very active, use 1.5‚Äì1.7; and if you‚Äôre extremely active, use 1.8 or higher.

Now add in any extra calories you burn from exercise or other activities throughout the day. The resulting number is your approximate calorie intake for the day.

Basal metabolic rate:

Basal metabolic rate (BMR) is the number of calories your body needs to maintain its basic functions while you are at rest. This includes functions like breathing, circulating blood and keeping your heart beating.

How to Calculate Your Basal Metabolic Rate:

To calculate your basal metabolic rate (BMR), you‚Äôll need to know your weight, height, and age.

You can use this online BMR calculator to do the math for you.

Once you have your BMR, you can use that number to help you determine how many calories you need each day to maintain your current weight.

To lose weight, you‚Äôll need to eat fewer calories than your BMR; to gain weight, you‚Äôll need to eat more.

Remember that these are general guidelines, and everyone‚Äôs needs vary. If you‚Äôre pregnant or breastfeeding, for example, you‚Äôll likely need more than 2,000 calories per day.

If you‚Äôre very active, you may need even more. Talk with a healthcare professional if you‚Äôre unsure about how many calories you should be eating.

How to Use the Diet Calories Calculator

The diet calories calculator is a handy tool for figuring out how many calories you need to eat each day in order to lose weight or maintain your current weight.

To use the calculator, simply enter your sex, weight, height, and age into the corresponding fields.

The calculator will then provide you with your basal metabolic rate (BMR), which is the number of calories you need to maintain your current weight.

To lose weight, you‚Äôll need to consume fewer than this number of calories per day.

To maintain your current weight, you‚Äôll need to consume the same number of calories as your BMR.

General Tips:

The number of calories in food is determined by the amount of energy that the food provides.

When you eat, your body breaks down the food into tiny pieces that it can use for energy. This process is called digestion.

The number of calories in a particular type of food is determined by how many nutrients it contains and how easily your body can digest it. Some foods are high in calories because they contain a lot of nutrients, such as protein, fat, or carbohydrates.

Other foods are high in calories because they are not very nutritious and are easy to digest, such as candy or processed snacks. If you eat something and then poop it out, the number of calories in that food would not be counted. However, if you ate something and it was absorbed into your body and used for energy, then the number of calories in that food would be counted.

If you throw up do you still count the calories?

Yes, you still count the calories! Throwing up does not get rid of the calories you consumed.

In fact, it can actually make you gain weight because you might eat more later to try to make up for what you threw up.

How many calories you need to eat to gain weight

How many calories you need to eat to gain weight depends on your Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) and how much you want to weigh.

To find out your BMR, use this calculator: www.bmi-calculator.net/bmr-calculator/.

Once you know your BMR, multiply it by the amount of activity you do in a day. If you are sedentary, multiply by 1.2. If you are lightly active, multiply by 1.375. If you are moderately active, multiply by 1.55. If you are very active, multiply by 1.725. And if you are extremely active, multiply by 1.9. This will give you the number of calories you need to eat each day to maintain your current weight (not including exercise).

To gain weight, add 500‚Äì1000 calories per day to this number (again not including exercise).

So if your BMR is 2000 and you are moderately active, you would need to eat 2500‚Äì3000 calories per day to gain weight.

How many calories should i eat for breakfast

There is no one-size-fits-all answer to this question, as the number of calories you need for breakfast will vary depending on your age, sex, activity level, and weight.

However, a good rule of thumb is to aim for around 400‚Äì600 calories for breakfast. This should provide enough energy to start your day without leaving you feeling too full or sluggish.

Some healthy breakfast options that are within this calorie range include: oatmeal with honey and banana; eggs with whole grain toast; yogurt with fruit and granola; a smoothie made with protein powder, almond milk, and frozen fruit.

How many calories do i need to maintain my weight

Maintaining weight is all about balancing the number of calories you consume with the number of calories you burn.

To maintain your weight, you need to eat the same number of calories that your body burns each day. This means that if you eat more than your body burns, you will gain weight; and if you eat less than your body burns, you will lose weight. There is no single magic number for how many calories everyone needs to maintain their weight.

It depends on factors such as age, sex, activity level, and muscle mass. However, general guidelines suggest that women need around 1,500‚Äì2,000 calories per day to maintain their weight, while men need around 2,000‚Äì2,500 calories per day.

If you are trying to maintain your current weight, aim to consume the same number of calories each day. To do this, keep track of the foods you eat and make sure that your calorie intake stays within your recommended range. You can use a calorie calculator or app to help monitor your intake, or simply keep a food journal to track what you ate throughout the day.

If you are looking to gain or lose weight, it‚Äôs important to adjust your caloric intake accordingly. For example, if you want to lose 1‚Äì2 pounds per week, aim to consume 500‚Äì1,000 fewer calories than your body needs each day. Conversely, if you want to gain 1‚Äì2 pounds per week, aim to consume 500‚Äì1,000 more calories than your body needs each day.

Conclusion

One of the most important aspects of maintaining a healthy lifestyle is controlling your calorie intake. It can be tricky, because you want to make sure you‚Äôre eating enough to fuel your body, but not so much that you‚Äôre packing on the pounds.

Luckily, there are plenty of ways to do this. One key is to make sure you‚Äôre eating nutrient-rich foods. These are foods that provide your body with the vitamins and minerals it needs to function properly. They‚Äôll also help keep you feeling full longer, so you won‚Äôt be as tempted to snack between meals. Some good options include fruits and vegetables, whole grains, and lean protein sources like chicken or fish.

Another thing to keep in mind is portion size. When dining out, for example, order an appetizer instead of an entree, or split a main course with a friend. At home, use smaller plates and measuring spoons to help control your portions. Finally, it‚Äôs important to get regular exercise.

This doesn‚Äôt mean hours at the gym every day; even moderate activity like walking or biking can help burn calories and keep your metabolism going strong. Just be sure to stick to a routine that works for you and fits into your schedule.

Friday, 28. January 2022

Oasis Open

OData Extension for Temporal Data v4.0 from OData TC approved as a Committee Specification

Handling time-dependent data using the Open Data Protocol (OData) The post OData Extension for Temporal Data v4.0 from OData TC approved as a Committee Specification appeared first on OASIS Open.

Extension for Temporal Data is ready for testing and implementation

OASIS is pleased to announce that OData Extension for Temporal Data Version 4.0 from the OASIS Open Data Protocol (OData) TC [1] has been approved as an OASIS Committee Specification.

This specification defines how to represent and interact with time-dependent data using the Open Data Protocol (OData). It defines semantics and a representation for temporal data, including operations for querying and modifying temporal data along with vocabulary terms to annotate which data depends on time, and how.

This Committee Specification is an OASIS deliverable, completed and approved by the TC and fully ready for testing and implementation.

The documents and related files are available here:

OData Extension for Temporal Data Version 4.0
Committee Specification 01
25 January 2022

Editable source (Authoritative):
https://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/odata-temporal-ext/v4.0/cs01/odata-temporal-ext-v4.0-cs01.docx
HTML:
https://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/odata-temporal-ext/v4.0/cs01/odata-temporal-ext-v4.0-cs01.html
PDF:
https://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/odata-temporal-ext/v4.0/cs01/odata-temporal-ext-v4.0-cs01.pdf
PDF marked with changes since previous public review:
https://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/odata-temporal-ext/v4.0/cs01/odata-temporal-ext-v4.0-cs01-DIFF.pdf

OData Temporal ABNF Construction Rules Version 4.0:
https://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/odata-temporal-ext/v4.0/cs01/abnf/odata-temporal-abnf.txt
OData Temporal ABNF Test Cases:
https://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/odata-temporal-ext/v4.0/cs01/abnf/odata-temporal-testcases.yaml
OData Temporal Vocabulary:
https://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/odata-temporal-ext/v4.0/cs01/vocabularies/Org.OData.Temporal.V1.xml

For your convenience, OASIS provides a complete package of the specification document and any related files in a ZIP distribution file. You can download the ZIP file at:
https://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/odata-temporal-ext/v4.0/cs01/odata-temporal-ext-v4.0-cs01.zip

Members of the OData TC [1] approved this specification by Special Majority Vote. The specification had been released for public review as required by the TC Process [2]. The vote to approve as a Committee Specification passed [3], and the document is now available online in the OASIS Library as referenced above.

Our congratulations to the TC on achieving this milestone and our thanks to the reviewers who provided feedback on the specification drafts to help improve the quality of the work.

Additional references:

[1] OASIS Open Data Protocol (OData) TC
https://www.oasis-open.org/committees/odata/

[2] Public reviews:
‚Äì Public review metadata record:
https://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/odata-temporal-ext/v4.0/csd03/odata-temporal-ext-v4.0-csd03-public-review-metadata.html
‚Äì Most recent comment resolution log:
https://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/odata-temporal-ext/v4.0/csd03/odata-temporal-ext-v4.0-csd03-comment-resolution-log.xlsx

[3] Approval ballot:
https://www.oasis-open.org/committees/ballot.php?id=3684

EdgeSecure

EdgeMarket Awards RFP For Help Desk Support Services to BlackBeltHelp

The post EdgeMarket Awards RFP For Help Desk Support Services to BlackBeltHelp appeared first on NJEdge Inc.

Newark, NJ, January 26, 2022 ‚Äì Edge, the region‚Äôs nonprofit research and education network and technology partner, has announced a partnership with BlackBeltHelp, to make their SIMPLIFY IT Help Desk Services available via its EdgeMarket Cooperative Pricing System. EdgeMarket provides safe, simple, smart technology procurement options for higher education and public sector entities. As the result of a thorough RFP process, EdgeMarket has awarded a contract which will give its participants the ability to efficiently and affordably procure IT help desk support services.

BlackBeltHelp‚Äôs SIMPLIFY IT Help Desk service offers flexibility, economy, and powerful tools that combine to increase service levels and end-user satisfaction while reducing overall cost of operations. Help desk services provided by BlackBeltHelp go beyond traditional IT, to include LMS, LMS, ERP, SIS and other live 24√ó7 help desk services.

‚ÄúEdge collaborated closely with our members and EdgeMarket participants to craft and award an RFP that meets their needs for help desk support,‚Äù said Dan Miller, Associate Vice President, EdgeMarket. Miller continued, ‚ÄúBlackBeltHelp‚Äôs reputation for excellence in 24√ó7 service for a wide range of applications makes them an ideal partner for EdgeMarket participants looking to lighten the help desk support load on internal teams. Working with a partner like BlackBeltHelp will enable IT staff to focus more on strategic, value-add initiatives, and less on transactional tasks like help desk tickets.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are excited about this strategic partnership with EdgeMarket. Edge understands the higher education landscape and has been adding value in the industry by empowering their community with affordable, efficient digital transformation technologies and services. We look forward to extending the value proposition by delivering best-in-class IT & OneStop student engagement support services, so that their members and EdgeMarket participants can enhance their user experience and achieve student success goals,‚Äù said Anthony R. Humphreys, President, BlackBeltHelp.
Today, BlackBeltHelp serves 200+ higher education clients, including Cornell University, UCLA, Pasadena City College, Community College of Baltimore County, and more. Help desk services provided by the organization have historically reduced average time-to-answer to less than 60 seconds, while reducing operational costs by up to 40%.

Existing Edge members and other institutions interested in leveraging the EdgeMarket purchasing consortium for access to streamlined technology purchasing and preferred pricing can find more information at https://njedge.net/solutions/edgemarket/.

About Edge:
Founded in 2000, Edge, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit corporation, serves as a purpose-built research and education wide area network and technology solutions partner. Edge connects members with affordable, easy access to high-performance optical networking, commodity Internet and Internet2 services, and a variety of technology-powered products, solutions, and services. The Edge member consortium consists of colleges and universities, K-12 schools and districts, government entities, healthcare networks, and businesses spread throughout the continental US. The group is governed by the New Jersey Presidents‚Äô Council with offices in Newark, Princeton, and Wall Township, NJ. For more information, please visit: www.njedge.net.

AVP for Marketing and Communications, Edge

adam.scarzafava@njedge.net

BlackBeltHelp is the #1 AI-powered Contact-Center-as-a-Service provider for students, faculty, and staff in higher education. Our solutions are designed to help higher education institutions unify all applications into a single, easy-to-navigate, analytics-powered dashboard to drive institutional processes and improve the user experience. Our integrated, omnichannel platform ‚Äì Simplify empowers the institution to integrate disparate systems across the campus to provide a simple yet powerful student service tool that increases institutional efficiency and helps in achieving engagement objectives effortlessly.

17:01 • 10 days ago

Energy Web

Elia Successfully Demonstrates TSO-visible EV Charging in Collaboration With Energy Web and BMW‚Ä¶

Elia Successfully Demonstrates TSO-visible EV Charging in Collaboration With Energy Web and BMW Group Berlin, Germany, and Zug, Switzerland, 27 January 2022‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäElia Group, the Belgian and German Transmission Service Operator (TSO), in collaboration with Energy Web, the non-profit building operating systems for energy grids, and BMW Group, has successfully demonstrated a TSO-visible EV chargin
Elia Successfully Demonstrates TSO-visible EV Charging in Collaboration With Energy Web and BMW Group

Berlin, Germany, and Zug, Switzerland, 27 January 2022‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäElia Group, the Belgian and German Transmission Service Operator (TSO), in collaboration with Energy Web, the non-profit building operating systems for energy grids, and BMW Group, has successfully demonstrated a TSO-visible EV charging session, laying the groundwork for improved EV charging, including renewable energy-only charging and fast supplier switching. In a demonstration at a public, fast-charging charge point from LamA in Berlin, Felix Kohlbrenner, research project manager at BMW Group, charged a BMW EV using this new solution, where the vehicle‚Äôs digital identity was securely shared with Elia. He also spoke with Helen Burgess from Elia about the solution and what it means for the future of EV charging. You can watch the full demonstration here:

The successful demonstration builds on Elia‚Äôs ongoing work with Energy Web on the E-Mobility Dashboard, an open platform designed to simplify the identification of EVs and charge points which enables all parties to receive trustworthy, secure data through Energy Web e-roaming hub, the Open Charging Network. This dramatically simplifies the process of data exchange between EV owners and participants of the energy sector, such as TSOs, energy suppliers, and flexible service providers. Typically, when an EV is charged, the local grid operator receives aggregated data on charging without receiving specifics on the individual vehicle. The same identities can be used to facilitate seamless payments with other market players, eliminating inefficiencies and oversharing of personal data.

Energy Web‚Äôs operating system enables digital identities to be assigned to EVs and stored on the vehicles‚Äô digital wallets. This enables the vehicle to securely share its identity with the TSO without having to share the driver‚Äôs identity. The demonstration showcases how more comprehensive and secure visibility can be achieved between participants in the charging process, as increasing the visibility of different assets in the system is fundamental to improving EV charging and enables future solutions including charging using 100% renewable energy.

‚ÄúBy assigning digital identities to EVs using Energy Web‚Äôs blockchain-based operating system, TSOs can finally benefit from visibility at the device level which they have never had before‚Äù, said Jesse Morris, CEO of Energy Web. ‚ÄúEV users benefit too‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääin the future, drivers will have their vehicle recognized automatically wherever they are charging and whichever operator they charge with, and will be able to receive a guarantee that they charged using energy generated exclusively from renewable sources.‚Äù
‚ÄúThanks to BMW Group for being involved with this exciting demonstration, a world-first for TSO-visible electric vehicle charging‚Äù, said Kai Schmied from Elia. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre looking forward to furthering our work with Energy Web on these cutting-edge charging solutions. Today, EV charging processes are not individually captured which prevents an active management of charging processes. Only with visibility on individual charging processes as well as a secure identification of involved participants, grid operators can enable flexibility use cases or offer new services such as supplier switching at the charging station‚Äô‚Äô.

About Energy Web
Energy Web is a global, member-driven non-profit accelerating the low-carbon, customer-centric energy transition by unleashing the potential of open-source, digital technologies. Our Energy Web Decentralized Operating System (EW-DOS) enables any energy asset, owned by any customer, to participate in any energy market. The Energy Web Chain‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe world‚Äôs first enterprise-grade, public blockchain tailored to the energy sector‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääanchors the EW-DOS tech stack. The Energy Web ecosystem comprises leading utilities, grid operators, renewable energy developers, corporate energy buyers, IoT / telecom leaders, and others.

Elia Successfully Demonstrates TSO-visible EV Charging in Collaboration With Energy Web and BMW‚Ä¶ was originally published in Energy Web Insights on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

Indonesia's GoTo and Nigeria's Flutterwave are among the giants expected to go public.
